content: The "400 Years of African-American History Commission Act" establishes a Commission to commemorate the 400th anniversary of the arrival of Africans in the English colonies in 1619. The Act defines key terms such as "commemoration" and "Commission." The "400 Years of African-American History Commission" is established with 15 members appointed by the Secretary based on recommendations from Governors, civil rights organizations, historical organizations, and the National Park Service. The "400 Years of African-American History Commission" has 15 members appointed by the Secretary based on recommendations from the Smithsonian Institution, Members of Congress, and others. SEC. 6. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission serve without compensation, except for federal employees who receive compensation from their government position. They are allowed travel expenses while performing Commission duties. The Chairperson has the authority to appoint a Director and staff for the Commission. The Chairperson of the Commission may nominate an executive director without following civil service laws, subject to confirmation by the Commission. The Commission can set compensation for the executive director and staff without adhering to certain provisions of the United States Code. The executive director and personnel's pay rate should not exceed level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal agencies can detail their personnel to assist the Commission without interrupting their civil service status. The Commission may accept state employees' services and reimburse the state for detailed personnel. The Chairperson can procure temporary services at specified rates. The Commission can also accept voluntary and uncompensated services as necessary. The Secretary shall provide administrative support services to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. Any reimbursement shall be credited to the appropriate account. This section does not override the National Park Service's authority regarding commemoration. The Commission is required to prepare a strategic plan, submit a final report to Congress by July 1, 2020, detailing activities, funds, findings, and recommendations. Appropriations are authorized for Commission activities until July 1, 2020, after which the Commission will terminate. The Commission will terminate on July 1, 2020, and all documents and materials will be transferred to the National Archives or another appropriate Federal entity before that date.
